Cultural globalisation: influence of foreign cultures through media, travel and migration; how Singapore maintains cultural heritage while embracing global cultural trends
Managing global challenges – Singapore’s response to issues like pandemics, climate change, terrorism (international cooperation and local initiatives to mitigate these challenges)
End of WWI and the 1919 Paris Peace Conference – Treaty of Versailles terms and its impact on Germany
Political and economic conditions in post-WWI Europe (instability, reparations burden on Germany, economic turmoil) that set the stage for extremist ideologies
Case study: Stalin’s rise in the USSR – consolidation of power (elimination of rivals, control of Communist Party), and impact of his policies (Five-Year Plans, collectivisation, purges)

Case study: Hitler’s rise in Germany – factors enabling Nazi rise (Treaty of Versailles grievances, Great Depression, charisma and propaganda), establishment of Hitler’s dictatorship (Enabling Act, Night of Long Knives)
The interwar experiences of citizens under these regimes (cult of personality, state control, suppression of opposition)

Secondary 3/4 History (Elective).topic: World War II in Europe and Asia–Pacific
subtopics: Outbreak of WWII in Europe (1939) – German expansion (invasion of Poland) and failure of appeasement; in Asia–Pacific (1941) – Japanese expansion and the attack on Pearl Harbor
Major theatres and turning points: war in Europe (Battle of Britain, Eastern Front Stalingrad, D-Day 1944) and war in Asia–Pacific (Battle of Midway 1942, island-hopping campaign)
Defeat of the Axis powers – factors such as Allied economic and industrial strength, strategic errors by Axis, development of the atomic bomb
End of WWII: Germany’s surrender (May 1945) and Japan’s surrender (Aug 1945 after atomic bombs), devastation in Europe and Asia

Secondary 3/4 History (Elective).topic: Cold War and the Bi-Polar World Order
subtopics: Origin of the Cold War – wartime alliances fraying, ideological clash between USA (capitalism) and USSR (communism), division of Europe with Iron Curtain
Early Cold War crises: Berlin Blockade (1948–49) and Airlift, formation of NATO (1949) and Warsaw Pact (1955), nuclear arms race (development of atomic and hydrogen bombs)
Concept of Mutually Assured Destruction (MAD) shaping superpower behaviour to avoid direct conflict
Global bi-polar alignments – how countries in Asia, Africa, Latin America were influenced (or chose non-alignment) during the Cold War era

Secondary 3/4 History (Elective).topic: Manifestations of the Cold War Outside Europe
subtopics: Korean War (1950–53): first “hot war” of the Cold War – North (with Chinese and Soviet support) vs South (UN/US support), stalemate leading to Korea’s continued division
Cuban Missile Crisis (1962): superpower confrontation over Soviet missiles in Cuba – brinkmanship and peaceful resolution, leading to improved communications (hotline) between superpowers

Vietnam War (USA’s involvement 1965–73): Cold War proxy conflict in Southeast Asia – Vietnam divided into communist North vs anti-communist South, heavy human and economic costs, eventual communist victory in 1975
These conflicts’ impact on superpower relations and local populations (destruction, casualties, shifts in public opinion against war)

Secondary 3/4 History (Elective).topic: Reasons for the End of the Cold War
subtopics: Internal economic weaknesses of the USSR – stagnation, inefficiencies of central planning, costly arms race with the USA
Gorbachev’s reforms (glasnost and perestroika from 1985) – attempts to open up society and restructure economy inadvertently weakening communist control
Mass movements in Eastern Europe (1989) – fall of Berlin Wall, collapse of communist governments in satellite states
Diplomacy and arms agreements (e.g., INF Treaty 1987) easing tensions; dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991 marking the Cold War’s end
Tourism industry and global trends – growth of international travel and tourism, factors driving increased tourism (higher incomes, better transport, globalization of travel)
Tourist types and motivations – categories of tourism (e.g., leisure, business, medical, eco-tourism) and what attracts tourists (natural vs cultural attractions)
Impacts of tourism on destinations – economic benefits (jobs, revenue), socio-cultural impacts (cultural exchange or dilution, crowding), environmental impacts (resource depletion, pollution)

Sustainable tourism management – strategies to minimize negative impacts (visitor quotas in fragile areas, community-based tourism, regulations) and roles of stakeholders (government, local communities, tourism companies)
Weather and climate basics – difference between short-term weather and long-term climate; elements of weather (temperature, precipitation, wind, pressure)
Global climate zones – characteristics of equatorial/tropical climate (high temperature and rainfall) vs other climates (desert, temperate, etc.)
Climate change and global warming – evidence of climate change, natural causes vs anthropogenic causes (greenhouse gas emissions)
Effects of climate change – rising sea levels for island nations, extreme weather frequency, impacts on food security and biodiversity
Responses to climate change – international efforts (e.g., Paris Agreement), national strategies (Singapore’s Climate Action Plan, Green Plan 2030) to mitigate and adapt to climate change
Structure of the Earth – crust, mantle, core; lithospheric plates and their movement driven by mantle convection

Plate boundaries – convergent (collision and subduction zones), divergent (sea-floor spreading, rift valleys) and transform boundaries; landforms and phenomena at each (mountains, volcanoes, earthquakes)
Volcanic eruptions and earthquakes – causes (build-up of pressure, plate movements) and primary/secondary effects on human societies (lava flows, tsunamis, destruction, casualties)
Case studies of tectonic hazards – example of a volcanic eruption (e.g., Mt Merapi) and an earthquake (e.g., Japan 2011) detailing impacts and responses
Disaster risk management – how countries prepare (hazard mapping, drills, building codes) and respond (evacuation, aid) to tectonic hazards to reduce damage
